fields.description:
To make the Projects page more useful, after clicking on a ProjectI can see all the Repositories that it contains.

I think it would be very useful to have a link on the left to view all Pull Requests for the contained repositories. As some devs work on all of the sub repositories, it would be a one stop shop for them.
fields.summary: Project Pull Requests

fields.description:
In the Branch page, when you create a PR using the "Create" button in the column page, it usually links the pull request #number (or link) to the branch's column.

!3861712291-branch_pr_links.png|thumbnail!

However, when you create a PR in the pull request page, the created pull request is not being linked to the branch column.

One thing I noticed is that when creating a pull request using the "Create" button in the branch's list column, there's parameter "*source*" included.

https://bitbucket.org/username/repo_name/pull-requests/new?source=feature%2Finitial_1.0&event_source=branch_list

But when creating a PR using the pull request page, there's no feature "source" parameter.

https://bitbucket.org/username/repo_name/pull-requests/new

h3. Expected Result
The created pull request in the PR page should be linked to the branch list column.

h3. Actual Result
The created pull request in the PR page isn't being linked to the branch list column.
fields.summary: UI: Branch Pull Request Column

fields.description:
When viewing all projects at https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/projects it'd be nice to have a repo count column for the projects.

After reorganising some projects, I had to just open every project in a tab to figure out which projects are now empty
fields.summary: Show repo count on project list

fields.description: When viewing a Project's Repository tab, it is currently locked to sorting by name. It'd be good to be able to sort by Last Updated
fields.summary: Sort by last updated on project repo list
Italics cause the cursor to get stuck when writing comments on PRs

fields.description:
We have two parallel steps that run on every PR for {{repository}}:

{code}
#!yaml

pipelines:
    pull-requests:
        '**':
            - parallel:
                - step:
                    name: PHP_CodeSniffer
                    caches:
                        - composer
                    script:
                        - composer install --prefer-source --no-interaction --dev
                        - vendor/bin/phpcs --report=junit --report-file=test-results/phpcs.xml .
                - step:
                    name: ESLint
                    caches:
                        - node
                    script:
                        - npm i --no-shrinkwrap
                        - npm run prod
{code}

On {{repository}}, I set up Slack chat notifications for "pipeline failed" and "pipeline fixed" to a particular channel, repository-wide. After pushing code to artificially trigger a pipeline failure, the notification appeared in Slack immediately after the pipeline failed. However, when pushing code to fix the failures, the pipeline completed but I did not receive a Slack notification.

I read the docs for chat notifications here, which describe "pipeline fixed" as "a successful completion after a failed attempt": https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/notifications-for-bitbucket-pipelines-857053284.html
fields.summary: Chat notification for "pipeline fixed" not firing on PR update

fields.description:
When opening a repository through the overview page on Bitbucket, the landing page is always the "Source" page, regardless of the setting checked on the settings page.

###Steps to repro###

# Have a repository with a landing page set up to something like the "Issues" page.
# Go to the Bitbucket's overview page (https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/overview)
# Under repositories, click on the name of the repository
# The landing page will be the "Source" page instead of the "issues" page

!605688053-Screen%20Shot%202019-01-09%20at%2010.38.35.png|thumbnail!\\
!3424074484-Screen%20Shot%202019-01-09%20at%2010.35.38.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Opening repository through the overview page does not load the correct landing page

Hi there,

I cannot leave a Bitbucket team that I don't want to be in. I don't know the administrator to get myself removed and have no admin access. I have also confirmed with a co worker in the same team and we both cannot leave the team.

I noticed there is in issue for this feature, however it is marked as resolved  while not actually working. [#14241|BCLOUD-14241%3F_ga%3D2.14406839.1033434433.1547004453-2001400553.1543359594]

Tully

fields.description:
As a devops engineer I would like queued single processor pipeline executions in branch scope. Currently in case where pipeline is making source changes merge conflicts might arise do to parallel executions leading to pipeline failure.

*Use case*

We have pipeline configured to patch package.json version and publish NPM package on branch push trigger. In case of concurrent executions version conflict arises both in branch and NPM registry.
fields.summary: Queued pipeline executions on branch

fields.description:
###Steps to Reproduce###

# Create a task from a comment in a pull request
# Reload the page.
# Click the "1 open task" link in the top right part of the pull request page
# In the modal that pops up, hover the task you created, to the right there's a hyperlink to the task
# The page will redirect to the comment that the hyperlink was intended for, as expected.
# Perform steps 3 and 4 again in the same page.

h3. Expected Results
h3. 
The page would redirect to the comment again.

h3. Actual Results
h3. 
The page does not redirect unless the page is refreshed and the steps are performed again.

h3. Notes
# If there are more than 1 open tasks, clicking on a hyperlink for a different task/comment after Step 5 will also not trigger a redirection.
# A similar behavior is also observed if the Hyperlink URL is opened via "Open in a new tab", it will not redirect to the comment as well.
fields.summary: Hyperlinks for open tasks in a Pull Request does not redirect on second or more attempts in the same page.

fields.description:
In reference to the clarification gained in https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-discussions/Faster-feedback-on-merges-with-pull-request-pipelines/m-p/968332#M1494 I would love support for re-triggering pull request builds when the target branch changes so that the PR pipeline result is always on par w/ the merge product the PR would result in.

According to Aneita Yang this is not yet possible and next step regarding this would be creating a feature request, which I'm doing here right now. As it's my first one, please excuse if I pressed some wrong buttons or selected inappropriate values. Also please ask any additional questions.

For completeness I also attached that discussion thread from the reference as PDF.
fields.summary: Gate-Keeper Builds for Pull Requests (PR)

fields.description:
Having started using Bitbucket very early on, I was able to "score" the {{marco}} account.\\
That is a source of pride most of the time.

Unfortunately, people are either careless, or incompetent, or just plain stupid, and keep adding me to their repositories, some of them containing proprietary, confidential source code - and there is no way to either refuse, or at least contact them and tell them I'm the wrong guy.

I'm sure this keeps happening to a lot of other folks too - and it's deeply annoying.

The only way I found is to create a PR and tell them - and, even that, sometimes gets ignored (which fills me with the urge of pushing a major {{git rm -rf .}} commit which I've been able to resist thus far, but who knows how long for yet)

Please consider some mechanism by which those of us who know what we're doing are able to communicate to those less fortunate than us; or at least, to turn down misguided additions.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Allow people to reject being added to a repository

fields.description:
Often users will change their email addresses and sometimes they create a new Atlassian account with the new email, rather than changing the email associated with their old Atlassian account. This causes problems because they can no longer access the Bitbucket content associated with their old login when using their new login, because the content belongs to separate Atlassian accounts. They can't just close their new account and change emails on the old one if they've created content (e.g. repos) in the new one already.

In these situations it would be useful to be able to merge their old account into their new account so they have access to all their content from one account, at which point they can close their old account.
fields.summary: Merge Atlassian Accounts

fields.description:
Scenario: I'm part of a team in a group with admin permission. I'm creating a private repository with the team as owner.

Result: I'm added to the repo user list with admin permission. This becomes a problem once I'm leaving the team. I'll be removed from any groups, with the intention of revoking all access to team repositories. But I'll retain admin privileges for any repo created by myself for that team. If I created 180 repos, the remaining admins will have to open the settings page of all 180 repos and remove me from the user list.

What would I expect: If I'm creating a repo with the team as owner, I should not be added to the repo user list at all.
fields.summary: Do not retain admin privilege for repo created for a team

fields.description: Currently, it's possible for the user to clone/download public repositories, please add an ability to disable it.
fields.summary: Ability to disable clone/download on public repositories

fields.description:
I'm trying to sync my code on a Ubuntu server with my repository on bitbucket.  The code on the remote server is owned by root user and as recommended by many experts, I have disabled root user's ability to log in to the server.  I've also set up a SSH key under my username on the server and added the corresponding public key to the bitbucket account for the repository in question.  Now I can access and sync code with bitbucket using the https URL:\\
sudo git pull https://<my_user_name>@bitbucket.org/<bitbucket_account_name>/<project_name>.git <branch_name>

Is there anyway to do log in with my user_name using the SSH URL instead?  If not, then what's the point of setting up a SSH key for my user_name and storing it in bitbucket?
fields.summary: Access bitbucket as a different user with SSH

fields.description:
Hi, I tried to use $BITBUCKET_BRANCH variable in custom pipelines step and the variable has no value. However it works if I access $BITBUCKET_BRANCH variable in default step.

{code}
image: maven:3.3.9

pipelines:
  custom:
   Build-Deploy-War:
      - step:
          name: Build Application          
          caches:
            - maven
          script:
            - echo $BITBUCKET_BRANCH # no value printed :(
{code}
fields.summary: $BITBUCKET_BRANCH variable has no value while running in common step

and have a repo created

fields.description:
You should use the "heavy_check_mark" in the Slack message rather than the white one\\
!1579564996-white%20check%20mark.jpg|thumbnail!

It would be aligned with your message in case of failure (red icon - red bar)

!1824978624-Pipeline%20issue.jpg|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Align the pipeline information in Slack

fields.description:
It would be good to enhance the manual pipeline stages somewhat by enabling the user to select which manual stage they wish to run.

An example where this would be extremely useful would be multiple development environments. We have one staging and one production environment so after a build there is a manual stage the user can select to deploy to the staging environment and then another manual stage that then allows them to deploy the artefact to the production environment. The way the stages work makes this really nice because you HAVE to successfully deploy to staging before you even get the choice to deploy to production.

However, we have multiple development environments and at present if we had multiple manual deployment stages for each development environment we would have to go through each one in order, ideally I would like to select a manual stage I would like to run and not have to go through previous manual stages to get there.

A nice a logical way of doing this would be if you had multiple manual stages inside a parallel container, it would allow you run any of the manual stages in that group, completely unlinked from one another.
fields.summary: Optional manual Pipeline stages

fields.description:

fields.description:
It seems there are some strange state changes when editing groups. Steps to reproduce:

*Initial State*:\\
Create Repositories = unchecked\\
Administer team = unchecked\\
Recieve Notifications = checked, greyed

*Now*:

# Click "Administer team"\\
2 Click the the cancel button.
# Click Edit button on the group

*New state*:\\
Create Repositories = unchecked\\
Administer team = unchecked\\
Receive Notifications = checked, not greyed -> Expected: checked, greyed

**Note: Not sure if there is a reason for the 'Administer team' checkbox when you're an administrator? Shouldn't this always be selectable? Should it really exist?

fields.description:

Basically every time I access a repository via bitbucket website, I just want to look into commits in that repository. Currently I have to click Commits icon at left all the time when I open a repository.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Default to "Commits" view when opening a repository

fields.description:
We've run into a few issues with these new v2 routes where the documentation doesn't match the functionality and are hoping to have these addressed in some way.

* GET /2.0/repositories/{username}/{repo_slug}/deploy-keys returns the array of keys, but none of them contain the "pk" field as documented.  The pk can be obtained by parsing the "links.self.href" but that is not ideal.
* POST /2.0/repositories/{username}/{repo_slug}/deploy-keys returns an object that does not contain the "pk" field.  It does contain an "id" field, which is not documented, but this field is _not_ the same as "pk". You can't use it for a GET or a DELETE. I'm not sure what it's the ID of. Ideally POST would return the pk.
* GET /2.0/repositories/{username}/{repo_slug}/deploy-keys/{pk} does correctly return the "pk" field (though it's not particularly useful in this case since you must've already known it)
* DELETE seems to behave as expected once you have the correct pk.
fields.summary: v2 deploy keys API inconsistencies
LFS over https: Authorization error

fields.description: There are lots changes to 300+ files, but I can't see them. Likely it is related to the fact that I've have amended some changes to local commit made previously. Actually in BB I can't see exactly these amended changes.

fields.summary: Deleting Failed Builds

fields.description:
Browser: Safari

Problem statement:\\
Bitbucket Branch Permissions Edit UI is distorted when the number of users requires text area to expand.

Screenshot included to demonstrate issue.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Branch Permissions Edit UI is distorted when the number of users requires text area to expand.

fields.description:
It looks like you recently changed the behavior on the branches page.  Previously when I clicked the ellipsis menu and selected sync, I would remain on the same page.  I'm now taken to the list of commits for the branch.  This is a massive hit to my productivity.  I work on a project that has anywhere from 30-60 ongoing branches at anyone time.  When I release code, I sync up all the branches with master and notify the devs of the branches that have conflicts.  In an ideal world there would be an option to sync all that would result in syncing the branches with no conflicts and return a report of the branches that failed to sync due to conflicts.  At very least, please keep the user on the branches page with the same sort after syncing via the ellipsis menu.

https://bitbucket.org/ispottv/web/branches/?sort=behind
fields.summary: Reimplement sync/merge behavior in on new branch list page

fields.description:
Sometimes,  a PR is massive, or has updates to multiple files. It would be nice to have the ability to approve files as you go through them. For instance, if a PR has 5-35 files in it, as you review a file, there could be an "approve" button  at the top of the file (like where the "side-by-side", "view file", and  "comment" buttons are.\\
Ideally, the user would review this code, find no error, click approve...and this file field would collapse to one line.\\
This would make the code review process easier and help shorten the screen for long pull requests.
fields.summary: Add feature to approve code by file

script:\\

I am unable to get any response by when i fetch or pull.\\
I aware that bitbucket is depreciating tls1 and 1.1, I did a check before dec 1 that my server supports tls1.2 (https://bitbucket.org/blog/deprecating-tlsv1-tlsv1-1-2018-12-01) and had a successful pull on dec 13, but now it doesn't gives any response when i do git fetch or pull. I used ssh to clone the repo.

When I run GIT_CURL_VERBOSE=1 git ls-remote https://bitbucket.org/ I get the following response:

* Couldn't find host bitbucket.org in the .netrc file; using defaults
* About to connect() to bitbucket.org port 443 (#0)
* Trying 18.205.93.1... * Connected to bitbucket.org (18.205.93.1) port 443 (#0)
* Initializing NSS with certpath: sql:/etc/pki/nssdb
* timed out before SSL handshake
* NSS error -5998
* Expire cleared
* Closing connection BCLOUD-0
* Couldn't find host bitbucket.org in the .netrc file; using defaults
* About to connect() to bitbucket.org port 443 (#0)
* Trying 18.205.93.1... * Connected to bitbucket.org (18.205.93.1) port 443 (#0)
* timed out before SSL handshake
* NSS error -5998
* Expire cleared
* Closing connection BCLOUD-0\\
error: timed out before SSL handshake while accessing https://bitbucket.org//info/refs

fatal: HTTP request failed

My server details are:\\
CentOS 6.10\\
Git 1.7.1\\
NSS 3.36.0\\
OpenSSL 1.1.0\\
Please let me know if there is any other info needed.

Any idea what is going on here?
fields.summary: No response when git pull / fetch

fields.description:
On the following documentation, it's defined that using the "pull-requests: '**'" definition will run Pipelines for every pull request created on the repository.

https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/configure-bitbucket-pipelines-yml-792298910.html#Configurebitbucket-pipelines.yml-ci_pull-requestspull-requests

However, if a pull request is created while having a source branch which does not include the "pull-requests: '**'" on the Bitbucket-pipelines.yml definition, the build is not triggered.

For example, lets suppose I have two branches, master and development, each with their YML set up like this:\\
!3333532819-Screen%20Shot%202018-12-28%20at%2016.23.24.png|thumbnail!

!4133817884-Screen%20Shot%202018-12-28%20at%2016.23.50.png|thumbnail!

In this case, it's not clear which YML file should be considered during the creation of the pull request. I would assume, in this case, that the YML to be considered here is the one on the destination branch, which contains the following definition for pull requests:

{code}
#!bash

pipelines:
  pull-requests:
    '**':
{code}

Creating the pull request, however, does not seem to trigger any builds:\\
!4148413479-Screen%20Shot%202018-12-28%20at%2016.25.53.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Pipelines' YML file for Pull-Requests definitions

fields.description: Sometimes in the pull request diff the line numbers are off. I'm sure that both files are the same. I made a new commit after creating the pull request that created many new lines. I'm not sure if that's whats causing it.

{{https://bitbucket.org/org_name/repo_name/rss?token=xyz}}

However, the *token* is changing once a while - so all my feeds stops working and I have to change their url.

Why is that?

fields.description:
I would like to upload the full source code for a software program.  The programmer wants to ensure that I do not have access to it until my final payment is rendered.\\
That is fine, but I want to make sure that the final source code is placed in BitBucket to protect it.\\
We agreed to have both authorizations required before either of us can access the code,

i.e. BOTH the programmer authorization and my authorization is needed before the code is available to either of us.

Today on Bitbucket, there are a total of three pull request statuses:\\
Open, Declined and Merged.

It would be great to have in between statuses such as "Working on", "Needs work", etc
fields.summary: Add transitional pull request statuses

fields.description: When I create a group, I can't select what repositories I want to give my group access, Sometimes we have contractors, I don't want to give them access to all my repos, Sometimes I have a group for android developers, I don't want to give them access to all my repos where maybe some of them are web applications when they make android apps. I would like to have more control what group can see what repository.
fields.summary: Select what repositories I want my groups have access

fields.description:
If the user has a free SourceTree license associated with their email address, when they try to delete their Atlassian account  associated with the same email adress, hey will be presented with the message :\\
"You can't delete your account

Your account can't be deleted because:

* This account is the primary billing contact for one or more products.
* This account is a technical contact for one or more products."

Our team is currently working on addressing this issue and we will update this public issue as soon as this is deployed.
fields.summary: Users that have an active SourceTree license are not able to delete their Atlassian account and Bitbucket Accounts

fields.description: When adding a branch permission, the options to "Allow rewriting branch history" and "Allow deleting this branch" are not present until a user or group has been entered providing no information to the user that such an option might become available.  If these options were disabled and grayed out then users would know that they are there.
fields.summary: Branch permission options are not present until a user or group has been entered

fields.description:
The initial Bitbucket Pipelines configuration which is available from bitbucket.org has some blocking mistakes which won't allow to proper get packages, build and run unit tests for golang.

The first problem is with added "" before each variable (i.e.: ${GOPATH} or ${BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER} - should be ${GOPATH} and ${BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER}.\\
After this fix the second issue will be raised if the developer created sub-folders (which is probably the case for every repo) i.e.:

{code}
#!python

root ---
-------- example1
----------- main.go
-------- example2
----------- main.go
----------- main_test.go
{code}

To fix this issue it is needed to add ./... for all three go commands at the end of the script (go get -v, go build -v and go test -v should be go get -v ./..., go build -v ./... and go test -v ./...).

This fix allows correct execution of the build on Pipelines for golang.
fields.summary: Initial Bitbucket Pipelines configuration for golang contains mistakes

fields.description:
The [API docs|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/meta/filtering/] specify the endpoints that can make use of filtering and sorting. I was very surprised to see that {{/2.0/repositories/{username}/{repo_slug}/commits}} is not one of those endpoints.

With large repos, it would be very helpful to be able to filter and sort the list of commits on the server, rather than retrieving thousands of commits in order to filter and sort locally.

Please consider adding filtering and sorting to the commits endpoint.
fields.summary: Add filtering and sorting to commits endpoint

fields.description:
My typical "Release and deploy" pipeline consists of the following steps:

* run tests
* build new docker image and push it to a registry
* deploy that image to kubernetes

From pipeline output I see that every step starts from "Build setup" where repo is cloned and git is configured with different params. Sometimes this setup can take up to 1 minute.

However, the repo initialisation is needed only on certain pipeline steps, such as tests running and docker image building, and there is no point to do it on the last deployment step.

Skipping the repo initialisation in that case can nicely reduce the pipeline execution time.

I would like to have a way to specify "clone" setting at specific step with value "no" (0 or whatever) which will allow me to skip that repo cloning
fields.summary: Way to prevent repo cloning on specific steps

fields.description:
Hi, I would like to change my username to all lowercase (*calvinize*), but when I tried changing it I got this error message:

_An account with that name already exists._

Can you please update my username to all lowercase please? Thanks.
fields.summary: Changing my username to all lowercase

fields.description:
Currently, if we enable "Deployments" in a repository if there are no changes made to the file *bitbucket-pipelines.yml*. It will still push commit with empty changes.

!3183418654-deployments_empty_commit.png|thumbnail!

It would be best if it will not automatically push a commit if there are no changes.
fields.summary: Deployments Configuration empty commit

fields.description:
We have configured a pipeline like this:

{code}
image: piotrpatrzek/atlas-plugin-build

pipelines:
  pull-requests:
   '**': 
      - step:
          script:
              - echo $BITBUCKET_BRANCH
              - atlas-mvn clean verify sonar:sonar --batch-mode --errors -Dsonar.bitbucket.repoSlug=jsd-extender -Dsonar.bitbucket.accountName=deviniti -Dsonar.bitbucket.teamName=deviniti -Dsonar.bitbucket.oauthClientKey=SM8aPfmkGFXXrvUQVv -Dsonar.bitbucket.oauthClientSecret=$SONAR_BITBUCKET_OAUTH_CLIENT_SECRET -Dsonar.bitbucket.branchName=$BITBUCKET_BRANCH -Dsonar.host.url=https://sonarqube.deviniti.com -Dsonar.login=$SONAR_LOGIN -Dsonar.password=$SONAR_PASSWORD -Dsonar.analysis.mode=issues
 
   
  branches:
    develop:
       - step:
           deployment: test
           caches:
             - maven
             - node
           script:
             - atlas-mvn clean verify


{code}

It doesn't run on pull Request created on any of the defined branches in our project
fields.summary: pipelines don't fire on pullRequest

fields.description: Not an issue, just found with really long PR's hitting the pageUp button, or scrolling indefinitely is not great. I'll let you guys figure out the best way to do it :smiley:
fields.summary: A way back to the top :)

fields.description:
If we could update the "add reviewers" input field logic so that it allows you to type a full\\
username and add that person as a reviewer (as I'm able to do in the\\
"default reviewers" input field)

It'd be great if the search kept refining itself as I typed, allowing me to actually select the user I want without typing out the full name. I understand that this is a bigger ask,\\
though I'd argue still quite doable.
fields.summary: Unable to add reviewers on pull requests (public repository / forked repository)

fields.description:
Situation:

I have a bitbucket Cloud repository that I want to send trigger notifications to Jenkins on for New and updated PRs. This webhook should work(it works in other bitbucket cloud accounts and it works against other Jenkins instances) but in my current bitbucket cloud account it throws a NET_ERR. This error is not very informative and I do not know where in the webhook triggering the connection is breaking down because there is not any sort of stacktrace or specific error message. I am not sure if this is just a HTTP error and I am not getting the details or if this is an UnknownHost error.

Surrounding data:

# Jenkins does not receive this webhook because it does not trigger anything in the logs
# The ELB where this Jenkins instance is routed through does not get the request

My request:\\
Allow more information when triggering a webhook within Bitbucket Cloud

(By the way I work for CloudBees and this is a customers instance we are trying to troubleshoot)
fields.summary: Getting more information about what caused a NET_ERR status in a webhook is not possible in bitbucket cloud

fields.description: We have BitBucket connected (with all our Atlassian Products) to SSO through Centrify.  We have some users who can access our Repos through a browser, but when they try to clone (or push, or any other action) via command line, they are refused with an authenticated failed connection.  Users have tried using SSH keys and the problem persists.
fields.summary: Users not able to connect through command line

fields.description: If a user has multiple email addresses in his account, it should be possible to select the email address that should be used to do the merge commit. Ideally, this is a setting per repository so that the "normal" commits and the merge commits done via a pull request have the same email address.
fields.summary: Allow setting default email address per repository for PR merges per repository

fields.description:
In  the branch view it is not showing that the branch has a pending pull request and just continues to show "create".

See below for example:

!2689094658-2018-12-19_15h11_40.png|thumbnail!

!1174025011-2018-12-19_15h11_20.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Git Flow feature not linking branch

fields.description:
When "New Pull request experience is enabled"  in Bitbucket UI\\
If the PR is merged using Fast Forward Merge and closing of the source branch\\
the files changed will only show the files modified in the latest commit included in the PR, not all files that were modified.\\
Switching off the "New Pull request experience is enabled"  from Bitbucket Labs and view the same merged PR in the old view, will show correct number of files modified.
fields.summary: Using fast forward merge with branch closing using Bitbucket UI and new PR view

fields.description:
Bitbucket Pipelines currently allows you to commit back to a repository over HTTP without any additional configuration, however you cannot commit back to other repositories in your account.

Can you add a feature to allow committing back to another repository that I own without having to add configuration to my bitbucket-pipelines.yaml file.

Background: https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-Pipelines-articles/Pushing-back-to-your-repository/ba-p/958407
fields.summary: Allow pushing to other repositories under my account with no additional configuration

fields.description:
"*It would be nice to be able to request monthly builds of a repository, just to check that no dependencies have disappeared or become incompatible.

I find that once a week is a bit more often than I need for scheduled builds.*" - from some document feedback we received
fields.summary: Monthly scheduled pipelines

fields.description:
Currently when looking at my PRs in the list view, there is no way to see whether or not the PR has conflicts.

!2529315865-Screen%20Shot%202018-12-18%20at%2012.00.35%20PM.png|thumbnail!

Adding another column to show that it has conflicts would be very helpful, since the PR is categorically not ready for merging if it has conficts, regardless of any other information displayed.
fields.summary: Please show if a PR has conflicts when listing it
